title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: When Carlyle returned to Edinburgh, after school-mastering at Annan and Kirkcaldy between 18 14 and 1818, to support himself hereby taking pupils, it does not appear where he lived.

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: Carlyle had spent an unsettled and mainly joyless summer, while Mrs. Carlyle had gone on from her cousin's, at Auchtertool  Manse, Kirkcaldy, to Haddington, saddest and dearest of places to her, unvisited now by her for twenty-three years; indeed, ever since her marriage.

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: * Kirkcaldy Helen,' had left the Carlyles, and the presence of

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: Her ' little Fifeshire maid,' Kirkcaldy Helen, as Carlyle calls her, was no small solace to her in these suffering days.

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: In August of this year Carlyle was in Kirkcaldy, and his wife wrote him poor accounts of her health.

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: Since his retirement from his post of schoolmaster  in Kirkcaldy, in 1818, he had led a struggling life in Edinburgh, writing, reading, translating, at very moderate remuneration, borne down by poverty and dyspepsia.

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: Edward Irving had, as we have seen, left Kirkcaldy an engaged man, pledged to Miss Isabella Martin, who afterwards  became his wife.

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: Irving was now engaged to be married: his betrothed, Miss Martin, being the daughter of the minister in Kirkcaldy, where Irving had taken an appointment  as schoolmaster on leaving Haddington.

title: Oliver Cromwell's letters and speeches: with elucidations.
author: Cromwell, Oliver
snippet: The extreme party of Malignantsin the North is not yet quite extinct; and here is another extremeparty of Remonstrants in the West, — to whom all the conscientious rash men of Scotland, in Kirkcaldy and elsewhere, seem asif they would join themselves ! Nothing but remonstrating, protesting, treatying and mistreatying from sea to sea.

title: Oliver Cromwell's letters and speeches: with elucidations.
author: Cromwell, Oliver
snippet: Men of worship,the Minister in Kirkcaldy among others, are heard to say strangethings : " That a Hypocrite," or Solecism Incarnate, " ought notto reign over us ; that we should treat with Cromwell, and givehim assurance not to trouble England with a King ; that whosoever mars such a Treaty, the blood of the slain shall be on hishead ! " ' Which are strange words,' says Baillie, ' if true.'

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: It was at Kirkcaldy that we all read a " slashing article" (by Brougham, I should now guess, were it of the least moment) on Southey's "Letters to W. Smith, M.P.," of Norwich, a Small Socinian; personage, conscious  of meaning grandly and well, who had been deno'lincing him as " renegade " (probably contrasting the once " Wat Tyler " wi|,h the now laureateship)  in the House of Commons; a second back stroke, which, in the irritating circumstances of the "Wat" itself (repubhshed by. some sneaking  bookseller) had driven Southey to his fighting gear or polemical pen.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Late on in autumn I met my Jeannie at Kirkcaldy again; uncomfortably  lodged, both of us, and did not loiter (though the people  very kind) ; I was bound for Eoss-shire and the Ashburtons (miserable journey thither, sombre, miserable stay there, wet weather,  sickly, solitary mostly, etc., etc.); my wife had gone to her aunts' in Edinburgh for a night or two ; to the Haddington Miss Donaldsons ;* and in both places, the latter especially, had much to please her, and came away with the resolution to go again.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Above two years before, from Kirkcaldy, I had forwarded to some magazine editor in Edinburgh what, perhaps, was a likelier little article (of descriptive tourist kind after a real tour by Yarrow country into Annandale), which also vanished without sign ; not much to my regret that first one, nor indeed very much the second either (a dull affair altogether, I could not but admit), and no third adventure  of the kind lay ahead for me.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: In late autumn,  1816, I went to Kirkcaldy in like capacity, though in circumstances  "(what with Edward Irving's company, what with, etc., etc.) which were far superior.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Latish in the autumn some of the Kirkcaldy Martins had come.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Martiu of Kirkcaldy now become Ms life-partner ; off on a tour to the Highlands ; and the generous soul had determined to pass near Kinnaird (right hank of Tay, a mile below the junction of Tummel and Tay), where I then was with the Bullers, and pick me up to accompany  as far as I would.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Ah me ! ah me ! — I think there had been before this on Irving's own part some movements of negotiation over to Kirkcaldy for release there, and of hinted hox)e towards Haddington, which was so infinitely miserable! and something (as I used to gather long afterwards) might have come of it had not Kirkcaldy been so peremptory and stood by its bond (as spoken or as written), "bond or utter ruin, sir!" upon which Irving had honorably submitted and resigned himself.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Poor Margaret! Speak to her since the "good-bye then" at Kirkcaldy in 1819 I never did or could.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Kirkcaldy itself had many looms, had Baltic trade, had whale - fishery, etc., and was a solidly diligent, yet l)y no means a panting, puffing, or in any way gambling "Lang Town."

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: The Kirkcaldy population were a pleasant, honest kind of fellow- mortals ; something of quietly fruitful, of good old Scotch in their works and ways ; more vernacular, peaceable, fixed, and almost genial  in their mode of life than I had been used to in the Border home-land.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Irving was very good and jocnud-hearted : most blithe his good old lady, whom I had seen at Kirkcaldy before.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: The full rally was uot to be till Stirling ; even Piers was gone ahead ; and Irving and I, after an official dinner with the hurghal dignitaries of Kirkcaldy, who strove to be pleasant, set out together one gray August evening by Forth sands towards Torryburn.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: In Kirkcaldy circles (for poor Kirkcaldy had its circles and even its West end, much more genial to me than Annan used to be) Irving  and I seldom or never met ; he little frequented them, I hardly  at all.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: In Kirkcaldy circles (for poor Kirkcaldy had its circles and even its West end, much more genial to me than Annan used to be) Irving  and I seldom or never met ; he little frequented them, I hardly  at all.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Irving on the contrary was being licensed — probably through Annan Presbytery; but I forget the when and where, and indeed conjecture it may have been before my coming to Kirkcaldy.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: We lived habitually by their means in a kind of Edinburgh element, not in the still baser Kirkcaldy one, and that was all.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: We leapt out on Kirkcaldy beach about eleven p.m., and then heard sufficiently  what a misery and tremor for us various friends had been in.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Gradually the stars came out, and Kirkcaldy crept under its coverlid, showing  not itself but its lights.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Kirkcaldy was some five miles off, and probably the tide not in our favor.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: This was, perhaps, still the third day ; at all events, it was the day of Glen's sailing for St. Petersburg, while Irving and I went watching from Kirkcaldy sands the Leith ships outward bound, afternoon sunny, tide ebbing, and settled with ourselves which of the big ships was Glen's.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Four miles next morning to Dunfermline  and its crowded day, Chalmers maxiraus not disappointing; and the fourteen miles to Kirkcaldy ending in late darkness, in rain, and thirsty fatigue, which were cheerfully borne.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: The beach of Kirkcaldy in summer twilights, a mile of the smoothest  sand, with one long wave coming on gently, steadily, and breaking  in gradual explosion into harmless melodious white, at your hand all the way ; the break of it rushing along like a mane of foam, beautifully sounding and advancing, ran from south to north, from the West Burn to Kirkcaldy harbor, through the whole mile's distance.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: The beach of Kirkcaldy in summer twilights, a mile of the smoothest  sand, with one long wave coming on gently, steadily, and breaking  in gradual explosion into harmless melodious white, at your hand all the way ; the break of it rushing along like a mane of foam, beautifully sounding and advancing, ran from south to north, from the West Burn to Kirkcaldy harbor, through the whole mile's distance.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: I always ratlier liked Kirkcaldy to this day.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Blessed conquest of a friend in this world! That was mainly all the wealth I had for five or six years coming, and it made my life in Kirkcaldy (i. e., till near 1819, 1 think) a happy season in comparison, and a genially

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: George Irving, Edward's youngest brother (who died in London as M.D., beginning practice about 1833), had met me as he returned from his lessons, when I first came along the street of Kirkcaldy on that sunny afternoon (August, 1816), and with blithe looks and w^ords had pointed out where his brother lived — a biggish, simple house on the sands.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: And I can say there could no two Kaisers, nor Charlemagne and Barbarossa, bad they neighbored one another in the empire of Europe, have been more completely rid of all that sordes than were we two schoolmasters in the burgh of Kirkcaldy.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Several letters passed on the subject, and it bad l^een settled, sbortly before this meeting witb Irving, tbat I was in my near vacation -time — end of August — to visit Kirkcaldy, take a personal view of everything, and then say yes if I could, as seemed likely.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: In short, a portion, perhaps between a third and fourth part, of Irving's Kirkcaldy patrons, feeling these griefs, and finding small comfort or result in complaining to Irving,  had gradually determined to be off from him, and had hit upon a resource which they thought would serve.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Several months before this, rumors had come of some break-up in Irving's triumphant Kirkcaldy kingdom.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: But to understand the full chivalry of Irving, know first what my errand to Kirkcaldy now was.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: At first sight he heartily shook my hand, welcomed me as if I had been a valued old acquaintance, almost a brother, and before my leaving, after worship was done, came up to me again, and with the frankest tone said, " You are coming to Kirkcaldy to look about you in a month or two.

author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Irving was over, doubtless from Kirkcaldy, on his holidays, and had probably been dining with Nichol.
